verses.text: Then I looked up again and saw a flying scroll.
verses.comment: The vision of the flying scroll represents God's message of judgment and purification. Scroll imagery is also seen in Ezekiel 2:9-10, signaling prophetic authority and divine law.

verses.text: He said to me, 'What do you see?' I answered, 'I see a flying scroll, twenty cubits long and ten cubits wide.'
verses.comment: These dimensions match the porch of Solomon’s temple (1 Kings 6:3), suggesting a link between this vision and God’s presence among His people, hinting at a role for liturgy and sacramental signs.

verses.text: Then he said to me, 'This is the curse that goes out over the face of the whole land; for everyone who steals shall be cleaned out according to what is written on one side, and everyone who swears falsely shall be cleaned out according to what is written on the other side.'
verses.comment: The scroll embodies God’s law (cf. Ex. 20:15 and Lev. 19:12), carrying both judgment and purification. Notice the two main sins—stealing and false swearing—both affect communal holiness, a key biblical principle underlying the idea of sacred discipline.

verses.text: 'I will send it out,' declares the LORD of hosts, 'and it will enter the house of the thief and the house of him who swears falsely by my name. It will remain in his house and consume it, both timber and stones.'
verses.comment: Divine judgment thoroughly cleanses both the individual and the community. This anticipates a deeper purification, foreshadowing the necessity of a means by which God's people are made pure and holy.

verses.text: Then the angel who was speaking with me came forward and said to me, 'Lift up your eyes and see what this is that is going out.'
verses.comment: The angel acts as a guide and interpreter, continuing the pattern of angelic mediation seen in prophetic visions, underscoring the way God provides spiritual insight through chosen messengers and visible, tangible means.

verses.text: I asked, 'What is it?' He said, 'This is the measuring basket that is going out.' And he said, 'This is their iniquity in all the land.'
verses.comment: The measuring basket (Hebrew: ephah) symbolizes economic life and daily commerce. Sin is not just personal but corporate, invading all aspects of society—a reason for both personal and communal repentance.

verses.text: And behold, a lead cover was lifted, and there was a woman sitting inside the basket.
verses.comment: The woman represents personified wickedness, echoing prophetic metaphors (cf. Prov. 7:27; Rev. 17:4). The hidden nature of the sin is exposed by God’s action.

verses.text: And he said, 'This is Wickedness.' And he cast her down into the basket, and he put the lead cover on its opening.
verses.comment: Evil is restrained, but not yet destroyed—awaiting a final judgment. There’s a present and a future dimension to divine justice, paralleling the already-but-not-yet reality in biblical salvation history.

verses.text: Then I lifted my eyes and saw, and two women were coming out with the wind in their wings. They had wings like those of a stork, and they lifted up the basket between earth and heaven.
verses.comment: The women, with stork-like wings, are agents of removal, not deliverance—transporting wickedness away from God’s land. This demonstrates God’s sovereign power to remove sin and purify His people, hinting at a process of sanctification involving visible and invisible realities.

verses.text: I said to the angel who was speaking with me, 'Where are they taking the basket?'
verses.comment: The question’s focus is on the ultimate destination of iniquity. This underlines that judgment is purposeful and guided, never random.

verses.text: He said to me, 'To the land of Shinar, to build a house for her. When it is prepared, the basket will be set there on its base.'
verses.comment: Shinar refers to Babylon, a biblical symbol of rebellion against God (cf. Gen. 11:2). Evil is exiled to its place of origin and awaits a final, eschatological judgment—foreshadowing the ultimate victory over sin found in Christ and the formation of a purified people.
